NARRATIVE: During the investigation, it was discovered that the caregivers did not have visual and/or auditory awareness of each child when a child was injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based on information gathered during the course of the investigation, operation staff failed to appropriately supervise a group of children.  This resulted in one child being injured while in care and requiring medical attention.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: While playing hide and go seek in the dark, a child received an injury requiring medical attention.  The caregiver did not have visual awareness of children when she allowed children to play hide and go seek in the dark.  The caregiver was not able to intervene when necessary to ensure children's safety due to not being able to see the children while they played in the dark with the gym lights turned off.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based on the information obtained through investigation inspection and the review of documentation it was observed that the operation/caregiver did not provide adequate supervision. By not providing supervision, the risk of injury/harm to the child was increased.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Interviews were conducted with children and staff. Staff did not supervise the children properly prior to the incident on the playground which led to one child being put in a situation that placed him at risk of being injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: It was determined after the investigation that the caregiver was not properly supervising the child in care when she was injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: A child was injured while in the care of 2 caregivers. A small child sustained 2nd degree burns while under the care of caregivers and a result of not properly supervising or paying attention of their surroundings.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based on information gathered, caregivers in the room did not supervise in such a way to intervene to prevent harm. As a result, a child in care sustained an injury to his mouth.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based on the information obtained during the course of the investigation, a caregiver failed to supervise children in care as they climb a wood structure located on the playground using a nylon material that was attached to it.  This resulted in a child in care sustaining an injury that required medical attention.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based on the information gathered a caregiver inappropriately supervised children in the classroom. The caregiver was not aware of what the children were doing at all times "visible or audible" as a result a child was injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: A group of children that required two caregivers was being supervised by one caregiver.  This was corrected when another caregiver arrived at the center 20 minutes later.    12/22 This standard was evaluated in regards to the self-reported allegation of a child injury and reports alleging concerns with ratio and discipline and is found to be deficient.  Through interviews with caregivers and children it was found that a group of children that required two caregivers was left unsupervised by one caregiver causing the children to be at risk.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based on interviews, it was determined that a caregiver was not supervising appropriately in order to intervene when a child was injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: The caregiver was aware of the children's activities at the time of the injury.  The caregiver failed to intervene to ensure the child's safety.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based on the information gathered during an investigation, it was determined that a child was not being properly supervised when they were able to touch an electrical outlet resulting in an injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Caregivers are unable to explain how a child was injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based upon the information that was received and reviewed throughout the course of the investigation, it was determined that supervision was not appropriate when a child slid head first down a collapsible crawl tube and sustained an injury to their forehead from hitting the loose fill on the playground. The collapsible crawl tube was placed up on a little tikes climbing structure where and how it was not intended to be played with.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: A child received a minor injury to his had as a result of inadequate supervision by his caregiver.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated with regards to an investigation and found to be deficient. A caregiver did not closely supervise children when she allowed children to swing on the handrail of the equipment. Consequently, a child fell and sustained an injury that required medical attention.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: A child received an injury that required medical attention after getting his finger stuck in the door. The caregiver did not have knowledge about the injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based upon the information obtained during the investigation proper supervision was not being maintained when a child was injured while in care. Four caregivers did not maintain physical proximity necessary to intervene when necessary when a child was injured while being supervised by all four caregivers.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based on the information obtained, a four year old child walked out of a classroom with another adult unnoticed by his caregivers.  Child was found in the care of another caregiver across the hallway from his classroom.  Child was found unharmed and had no injuries.  The child was returned to his classroom.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Through information received during the inspection there is concern with supervision related to the injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: The caregiver was aware of the children's activities at the time of the injury.  The caregiver failed to intervene to ensure the children's safety when the children repeatedly returned to the nap mat closet to open and shut the door.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: During the course of this investigation, it was determined that supervision was not appropriate when a child was injured and no one knew how or when the child was injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: During an investigation it was verified that a caregiver did not  intervene when a child received injuries from another child.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Caregivers were unaware a child in care was  injured and required medical attention.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: The caregiver did not know how the 2yr old received an injury to her head.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: During an investigation it was verified that a caregiver in the infant room did not have visual on a child when they turned their back allowing the child to fall over in a high chair receiving a head injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Children were not supervised properly when a child was injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Children were not being supervised adequately on the playground when a child was able to jump off a slide unnoticed by three caregivers. An injury resulted of this jump.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: A child received a serious injury to her fingers, and the caregivers could not give an accurate statement on how one child was able to tip over a heavy bookshelf that fell on the child's hand. The caregivers could not determine if one or more than one child turned over the bookshelf.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: A caregiver neglectfully supervised the children in her care. As a result of this inadequate supervision a child was able to exit the building. This placed the child at significant risk for injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: The children are not properly supervised on the playground resulting in play fighting, hiding in a tunnel (play structure) and a child being injured by two other children.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated as part of an investigation and found deficient. While in care a child sustained a serious injury. Operation staff did not provide appropriate supervision as staff did not know how the injury occurred.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: A child had her finger injured when she had her hand on a door jam.   The door closed injuring her finger.  Two staff were present, but neither one saw that a second child had opened the door to the kitchen.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated with regards to an investigation and found to be deficient.  Based on interviews conducted, it was determined the caregiver could not account how a child was injured while using a piece of equipment.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: A child was injured in her classroom, and the caregivers were unaware that the child was injured during the time of play.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated as part of an investigation and found to be deficient. Many parents were interviewed and stated children have had many unexplained bruises, bite marks or other injuries and the teachers tell them they don't know how it happened.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated in regards to a report and was found to be deficient. A caregiver failed to intervene, when children were running inside of a classroom, and a  child fell and sustained an injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: A caregiver inappropriately supervised a child that was placed in a bouncer on the countertop by walking away from the child and resulted in the child being injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated with regards to an investigation and was found to be deficient.  A caregiver did not intervene appropriately when a child used an equipment that was not the intended use of the equipment. Consequently, a child sustained an injury that required medical attention.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: The two qualified caregivers were not properly supervising the infants when a 7 month old infant fell from a chair in the care of a lab student  after she unstrapped him from the chair and walked away.  The infant fell from the chair and hit his head on uncarpeted floor due to there being no person close enough to be able to prevent him from falling. The child received an injury that required medical treatment.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Caregivers did not observe the child getting injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based on observation of the video, it appears that supervision was not adequate when an injury occurred.  There were two caregivers in the room supervising but they were over on the tile area not facing the carpeted area.  The girls involved interlocked hands back to back and were turning a flip.  This happened twice but before the third time where the injury occurred.  This should have been noticed and addressed possiby preventing the injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based on interviews with operation staff, children, and parents, caregivers did not adequately supervise the children in their care and as a result a child sustained an injury and had to obtain medical treatment as a result.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based on the information received the caregiver was not properly supervising the group of children they were responsible for while outside on the playground. The caregiver was unaware of the child's activities and was unable to intervene when the child was injured while at play outside.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: The school age group was not being properly supervised when a child was injured during an altercation with another child.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based on statements from staff, and video provided by the center, there is evidence to support allegations that staff did not provide adequate supervision when one child threw another child to the floor in the climbing equipment, and then proceeded to throw another child on the floor, hit and kick that child until it appears the child cried out in pain.  Based on video provided, the staff failed to provide adequate supervision when a three year old child was observed climbing in and out of the play house window, over a faux picket fence, which may have led to her sustaining a minor injury.  Based on observations during the inspection, staff failed to provide adequate supervision when a staff member's child was allowed to continuously leave the play area and seek out her mother in another room of the facility.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated as part of an investigation and found to be deficient. Caregivers were not appropriately supervising a small group of children. As a result, a child in the group was injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated with regard to an investigation in which a child was injured.  The child fell on concrete causiing the scrape on the forehead.  The child had also bitten 2 times during only a week at the operation.  There are only 3 children in the classroom of children between 18 months old and 2 years old.  A child this young should not have been allowed to run on the concrete area since children under 2 years old tend to fall often as their coordination is not developed yet.  The caregivers should be on the floor interacting with the children so she can teach them to share and ease frustration before biting occurs.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: A child received an injury while in care to both sides of his head. Information supported the injury occurred while in care; however, the caregivers were not able to explain how the injury was obtained.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Caregivers in a pre-school age classroom failed to properly supervise and intervene after a child stood on and jumped off a plastic bin numerous times. The child was then pushed while standing on the bin resulting in an injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based on information obtained during Investigation, caregiver was not properly supervising children when a bench in the restroom fell on a child's foot and cause an injury which required medical treatment.    There is insufficient information to indicate that biting is occurring in the class due to a lack of supervision.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(4) - Responsibilities of Caregivers- Supervision of Children

NARRATIVE: Based on information obtained during the investigation, it was determined that five to seven school age children were out ot control when transitioning to the playground.  The caregiver gave verbal redirection for two children to get down from the picnic table and when the caregiver turned around there were additional children standing on top of the picnic table.  As a result of the children's behavior, one child was injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(5) - Responsibilities of Caregivers - Children in Control

NARRATIVE: Children are not being properly supervised, there are no lesson plans or activity plans. As a result children are out of control horse playing and being injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(5) - Responsibilities of Caregivers - Children in Control

NARRATIVE: Based on information gathered, an injury to a child in care occurred when the caregiver lost control of the two year old group while transitioning to outdoor play.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(5) - Responsibilities of Caregivers - Children in Control

NARRATIVE: The caregiver failed to keep children in control which caused an injury to a child and allowed children to exit the classroom and building without the caregiver.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(5) - Responsibilities of Caregivers - Children in Control

NARRATIVE: Based on the video footage the classroom was not in order. The children were left unsupervised by their teacher. The children are observed to be running around in the classroom. Due to the classroom being out of order it caused for a child to get seriously injured. A child was hit by another child who was running around causing the child to sustain a slight concussion and a bruise on her forehead.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(5) - Responsibilities of Caregivers - Children in Control

NARRATIVE: Based on interviews with children, staff and a parent, it was determined that there have been a few incidents in which children were not kept under control, causing injuries to some children while fighting.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(5) - Responsibilities of Caregivers - Children in Control

NARRATIVE: Based on the information gathered during the investigation, children in the operation were out of control when a child's leg was injured in the process.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(5) - Responsibilities of Caregivers - Children in Control

NARRATIVE: Two children were fighting, which led to injuries to one child.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(5) - Responsibilities of Caregivers - Children in Control

NARRATIVE: Caregivers in the school age room are not ensuring that children remain in control. There has been a pattern of hitting, pushing, and throwing of toys and equipment in the school age room that has led to minor injuries.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(5) - Responsibilities of Caregivers - Children in Control

NARRATIVE: The children in the Toddler classroom were observed to not be following the activity schedule and the caregiver responsible had no control of the children. While observing the classroom, children were observed playing with wipes. The children were wiping the floor with the wipes as well as placing them in their mouths. One child fell on his back and hit his head while another child's finger was injured. When informed that the activity schedule was not being followed the caregiver began to calm the children at the table with books as she cleaned the classroom.     At 12:02pm during nap time a child ran out of the Toddler classroom with two caregivers present.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(5) - Responsibilities of Caregivers - Children in Control

NARRATIVE: The Children were allowed to run in the cafeteria in an attempt to get in line. As a result, an injury occurred.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(5) - Responsibilities of Caregivers - Children in Control

NARRATIVE: Caregiver was involved with janitorial duties and not properly supervising a child.  The child was observed running around the classroom fell and received an injury requiring medical attention.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(6) - Responsibilities of Caregivers - Free of other activities

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated in regards to  a report and found to be deficient.  A caregiver was distracted by a cell phone while responsible for children. A child sustained an injury while the caregiver was distracted by a cell phone.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(6) - Responsibilities of Caregivers - Free of other activities

NARRATIVE: Based on the evidence obtained during the investigation the caregiver in charge of two children was completing janitorial duties that included cleaning the top of shelves, stacking shelves and emptying the trash can when the two children climbed onto a table and one child pushed the other child resulting in an injury. Due to the caregiver not being free of other activities it impacted her ability to adequately supervise resulting in a child injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(6) - Responsibilities of Caregivers - Free of other activities

NARRATIVE: Based on information gathered, children were allowed to go to the restroom without adult supervision. As a result, a child's finger was injured and required medical attention. The caregiver was not aware of what occurred until after the child was heard screaming.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(6) - Responsibilities of Caregivers -Free of other activities

NARRATIVE: Based on the evidence obtained a caregiver was distracted with completing paperwork and distracted from appropriately supervising the children which led to a child injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(6) - Responsibilities of Caregivers -Free of other activities

NARRATIVE: Based on the information gathered the caregivers were using their cell phones in direct care of a group of children in the school age classroom when a child was injured and required medical treatment.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1203(6) - Responsibilities of Caregivers -Free of other activities

NARRATIVE: The records of employees hired on 3/30/17 and 4/5/17 did not include the required orientation.  Lacking was orientation in the following:  (1) Administering medication;   (2) Preventing and responding to emergencies due to food or an allergic reaction;  (3) Understanding building and physical premises safety, including identification and protection from hazards that can cause bodily injury such as electric hazards, bodies of water, and vehicular traffic; and  (4) Handling, storing, and disposing of hazardous materials.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1301(a)(1) - Training Requirements for Employees - Orientation

NARRATIVE: The orientation does not contain preventing and responding to emergencies due to food or an allergic reaction; understanding building and physical premises safety, including identification and protection from hazards that can cause bodily injury such as electric hazards, bodies of water, and vehicular traffic; or handling, storing, and disposing of hazardous materials.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1301(a)(1) - Training Requirements for Employees - Orientation

NARRATIVE: A caregiver who was responsible for a child who sustained an injury that required emergency medical attention did not have current CPR/FA. The caregiver's CPR/FA had expired on 8/13/16, and the child sustained the injury on 9/16/16, while in the caregiver's classroom.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1301(a)(5) - Training Requirements for Employees - CPR and First Aid

NARRATIVE: Based on information obtained during the investigation the operation does not have proof that the caregiver who provided first aid to an injured child had current training in first aid.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1301(a)(5) - Training Requirements for Employees - CPR and First Aid

NARRATIVE: Two caregivers hired after 9/1/16 lacked the following orientation training: (1) Administering medication(2) Preventing and responding to emergencies due to food or an allergic reaction(3) Understanding building and physical premises safety, including identification and protection from hazards that can cause bodily injury such as electric hazards, bodies of water, and vehicular traffic(4) Handling, storing, and disposing of hazardous materials including compliance with ?746.3425 of this title(5) Precautions in transporting children if your center transports a child whose chronological or developmental age is younger than nine years old.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1303(a)(1) - Orientation-Minimum Standards

NARRATIVE: Additional orientation training topics for a caregiver hired on 11.14.16 has not been completed to date. STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1303(a)(1) - Orientation-Minimum Standards

NARRATIVE: One caregiver hired after 9/1/16 lacked the following orientation training: (1) Administering medication(2) Preventing and responding to emergencies due to food or an allergic reaction(3) Understanding building and physical premises safety, including identification and protection from hazards that can cause bodily injury such as electric hazards, bodies of water, and vehicular traffic(4) Handling, storing, and disposing of hazardous materials including compliance with ?746.3425 of this title(5) Precautions in transporting children if your center transports a child whose chronological or developmental age is younger than nine years old.

NARRATIVE: This standard was reviewed on 09/12/2017 as a  follow up to a monitoring inspection in which was conducted on 08/23/2017 and found deficient. An employee who was hired in 1/2017 did not have documentation of orientation in the following:  1) Preventing and responding to emergencies due to food or an allergic reaction;  2)  Understanding building and physical premises safety, including identification and protection from hazards that can cause bodily injury such as electric hazards, bodies of water, and vehicular traffic;  3) Handling, storing, and disposing of hazardous materials including compliance with ?746.3425 of this title (relating to Must caregivers wear gloves when handling blood or bodily fluids containing blood?);  4) Precautions in transporting children if your center transports a child whose chronological or developmental age is younger than nine years old; and 5) Precautions in transporting children if your center transports a child whose chronological or developmental age is younger than nine years old. NARRATIVE: A parent volunteer who was not qualified as a caregiver and did not have a background check for the facility was left alone with a child when she walked him back to the center from a field trip when he received an injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1401(f) - Substitutes, Volunteers and Contractors - Unqualified Not Left Alone with Children

NARRATIVE: Based on the information gathered throughout the investigation, one caregiver was left with a group of 24 children aged 3-4 years old. Note, this was to assist with an injured child.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1601 - Child/ Caregiver Ratio - 13 or More Children

NARRATIVE: There was one caregiver caring for 17 children ranging from 14 months-11 years old at arrivial to the center. Corrected at inspection when another caregiver arrived 20 minutes later.  12/22 This standard was evaluated in regards to a reported allegation of a child injury and is found deficient.  According to interviews with children and staff it is found that one caregiver was caring for 7 infants and 3 children over 18 months of age in one room.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1601 - Child/ Caregiver Ratio - 13 or More Children

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated in regards to an investigation and was shown deficient.  At the time a child was injured that required medical attention there were 32 children with one teacher supervising.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1601 - Child/ Caregiver Ratio - 13 or More Children

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated in regards to a reported allegation of a child injury and is found deficient.  According to interviews with children and staff it is found that one caregiver was caring for 7 infants and 3 children over 18 months of age in one room.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1601 - Child/ Caregiver Ratio - 13 or More Children

NARRATIVE: There was more than 18 months age difference when one caregiver was caring for 17 children ranging from 14 months to 11 years old.  Corrected at inspection when another caregiver arrived 20 minutes later to center.  12/22 This standard was evaluated in regards to the reported allegation of a child injury and is found to be deficient.  Based on documentation and interviews, the operation has two caregivers watching up to 22 children including 5 - 7 infants in one room until 8:00 a.m.  as well as interviews reporting that toddlers were placed in the infant room causing 18 months difference between oldest and youngest child.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1605 - Child/Caregiver Ratio - 18 Months Difference in Age

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated in regards to the reported allegation of a child injury and is found to be deficient.  Based on documentation and interviews, the operation has two caregivers watching up to 22 children including 5 - 7 infants in one room until 8:00 a.m.  as well as interviews reporting that toddlers were placed in the infant room causing 18 months difference between oldest and youngest child.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1605 - Child/Caregiver Ratio - 18 Months Difference in Age

NARRATIVE: There were 12 children on the field trip to McDonalds on the day a child was injured there and only one caregiver supervising.  When the age of the youngest child is 5 years old, there should be no more than 10 children supervised by one caregiver.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.1801(a) - Child/Caregiver Ratio for Field Trips - Areas Open to General Public

NARRATIVE: Based on information gathered during the course of the investigation it was determined that the permit holder did not ensure that policies for the designated person in charge at the operation included clear expectations for handling medical emergencies and situations requiring parent notification, including a timely notification of the incident to the director, while the director is on work time but is not physically present at the operation. This resulted in the director not being notified to begin contacting the parent regarding an injury that required medical attention until an hour after the incident occurred.     Based on information gathered during the course of the investigation it was determined that the permit holder did not ensure that there was a clearly outlined policy as to who is responsible for notifying the parents and emergency contacts when the parents cannot be reached while the director is not present at the operation. This resulted in the parent and/or emergency contacts not being notified of an incident that required medical attention until approximately 8 hours after the incident occurred.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.201(1) - Policies Comply with Rules

NARRATIVE: Based on the information gathered during the investigation, the daycare was aware that a child was coming to the operation with unexplained injuries and did not report it to DFPS.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.201(5) - Reporting Suspected Abuse, Neglect, Exploitation

NARRATIVE: Operation is aware that they are to report suspected abused.    This standard was evaluated as part of an investigation and found to be deficient. During the investigation it was determined that operation staff were aware of injuries and did not report suspected abuse
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.201(5) - Reporting Suspected Abuse, Neglect, Exploitation

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated as part of the investigation. Based on interviews it has been determined that this standard is deficient. Caregivers were aware that a child was crying but did not check on him, which resulted in injuries on the child.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.2401(3) - Basic Requirements for Infants - Holding and Comforting

NARRATIVE: I observed an accordian gate around the AC Unit that had a visible hole that is accessible to infants, that could possibly lead to injury
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.2415(3) - Prohibited Equipment for Infants - Accordion Safety Gates

NARRATIVE: Based upon the information obtained during the investigation, there was sufficient evidence to support the equipment in the two year old classroom was arranged to allow for proper supervision.  NOTE:  On the day of the incident when a child was injured, the caregiver was at the diaper changing area (back was towards the class), the wooden kitchen was in the middle of the floor (back of the kitchen was towards the caregiver's back).  Due to the placement of the play wooden kitchen and the diaper changing area - the caregiver's view of the children she was responsible for supervising was obstructed.  NOTE:  The wooden play kitchen had been moved to the back wall.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.2503(2) - Toddler Care Area - Allows for Proper Supervision

NARRATIVE: Based on the evidence obtained during the course of the investigation, including interviews, a child was injured by a writing desk that was not age appropriate for the child's classroom.

NARRATIVE: This injury suffered by the child would result from the child being grabbed forcefully by the arm. STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.2805 - Prohibited Punishments - No Harsh, Cruel or Unusual

NARRATIVE: At the last inspection, I observed the water fountain outside propped up by a stick.  The stick is gone now and it is standing on its own.   At the last inspection, there was a large hole in the side of the water fountain in the gym and it has been covered.   There was torn carpet throughout the facility at the last inspection and it has been replaced except for a few areas in the pre-K room.   I observed stained ceiling tiles at the last inspections and today there were still stained ceiling tiles.  There were several in the gym which were bulging out and look as if they coud fall through with any more rain.  The director states they continue to put new ceiling tiles up but when it rains it leaks again staining them again.  The leaks need to be repaired permenantly rather than just replacing the tiles every time it rains.  Rain is expected again in a few days.  At the last inspections, there were broken windows in the classrooms but they have now been repaired.  At the last inspections, the bus had small holes in the floor of the bus where the ground can be seen.  Those have now been covered.  At the last inspection,the steps into the bus were uneven and sounded as if the wood underneath was deteriorating.  At this inspection the steps were a little better and did feel hard as if new wood had been put underneath; however, the top step was still uneven where a child could fall easily off this step resulting in serious injury.  There was a metal strip by the steps that was  coming up at the last inspection and that has been corrected.  It was also noted at the last inspection that the washing machine leaked on the utility room floor when in use.  They did buy a new washing machine.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3407 - Maintenance of Building, Grounds and Equipment

NARRATIVE: Toys and equipment were found to be unmaintained and can increase the risk of injury to children.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3407 - Maintenance of Building, Grounds and Equipment

NARRATIVE: Upon investigation it was found the operation's fence was leaning and children were allowed to play near the fence.  This resulted in an injury to a child which required medical care.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3407 - Maintenance of Building, Grounds and Equipment

NARRATIVE: There are two buses that still have exposed stuffing with torn seats.     Three of the vehicles have torn seat exposing stuffing and metal framework. This could present a risk of injury to children while being transported.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3407 - Maintenance of Building, Grounds and Equipment

NARRATIVE: I observed the bathroom in the 4 to 5 year old classroom  light not working.  A staff member validated that the light has not worked in a month.  Having areas that are used  by children well lighted can prevent children from bumping into walls or object which could cause injuries.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3407(10) - Center Heated, Lighted and Ventilated Properly

NARRATIVE: Based on observation there is a missing tile in the centers main room. I observed the missing part has exposed broken wooden pieces that pose a possible hazard of a child obtaining a splinter or other type of injury from the broken wooden pieces on the floor. There is also peeling paint on the wall in the infant room. The paint is coming off the wall and there are pieces on the floor accessible to the infants in care. This poses a possible hazard should an infant indigest paint they come in contact with.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3407(9) - Floors, ceilings and Walls in Good Repair and Clean

NARRATIVE: There was an incident where a child sustained an injury requiring immediate medical attention. Caregivers failed to use gloves while administering first aid on a child.

NARRATIVE: A caregiver did not use gloves when a child sustained an injury that caused them to bleed.

NARRATIVE: While the operation notified the parent and provided first-aid, they failed to contact EMS for an accidental head injury.

STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: Several hazards were found during this inspection. The door to the laundry room that is off the younger infants' room does not close and has not lock. A child can easily enter the room where there is a washer, dryer, and laundry detergent on the floor.       The outdoor area has a wooded play structure. The steps to the structure are coming apart causing the long nails to be exposed. One nail was fully exposed and was sharp.     The school age room has seven bulky computers, one monitor, and one processor that are not connected or secured in any manner; thus they may fall on a child and cause serious injury.    Photos were taken.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: A shelf of cubbies was not securely anchored in the two year old room.  The shelf could have fallen on a child causing injury.      Extended compliance date based on the operation staff moving the self during the inspection, but still needed to bolt it in place.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: A baseboard in a classroom was observed broken and detached, leaving space between the wall for children to place their fingers in. Another baseboard in a classroom was observed missing, and screws were protruding.    This was corrected at inspection when the director placed shelves in front of the baseboard and removed the screws.     A mirror in a school age classroom was observed with a broken corner and a sharp edge which could cut children.     This was corrected at inspection when the director placed a shelf in front of the mirror to prevent children from being injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: A child sustained an injury while in care due to a broken gate. The gate's locking mechanism was broken and was swung open abruptly, causing injury to a child.      This was CORRECTED at inspection when all gates to the playground were observed with a locking device.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: Cabinets located in  classrooms did not contain locks.  The areas under the cabinets were large enough to fit a small child.     In the infant classroom, there was a sliding shelf at an infant's level that could injure a child if pulled out too quickly.      The gates located on the playground areas had openings that would allow a child to slide through.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: Metal water troughs were exposed to the sun and accessible to children on the playground. This resulted in any injury when a child came in contact with one of the troughs and sustained burns to the skin.     This was corrected at inspection when the water troughs were removed from the operation.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: During the walk through on the playground, I observed 2 broken boards with sharp edges which could cause injury to a child.     Note: Pictures were taken for the file.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: Plastic black barriers on the playground had screws that were lifted and not flush with the barrier itself. This can cause an injury if a child fell on a screw or his/her clothing items attached to the screw and caused a fall.     On the path to the playground, a piece of metal was protruding off the gym wall. This can cause an injury if a child fell on or rubbed up against the item.     Playground liner was exposed which is a trip hazard for the children.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: Observed a broken wood post barrier on the playground to which exposed a metal rod. This rod may cause an injury if a child were to fall on the item.     Observed lifted fence links on the right lower side of the playground. This may allow someone to enter or exit the playground area.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: I observed a unsecured tall book shelf capable of causing injury to a child should a child pull upon the shelf. The shelf was located in a classroom containing children 18 months- 3 years.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: A room caring for children ages 12 - 22 months, a shelf was observed to be shaky and unsteady. Injury may occur to a child if a child were to push over, fall upon the shelf causing the shelf itself to fall or the interior items to fall on a child.     A room caring for children ages 2 years old, a shelf was observed to be shaky and unsteady. Injury may occur to a child if a child were to push over, fall upon the shelf causing the shelf itself to fall or the interior items to fall on a child.     On the playground, observed a wood barrier for the loose fill to be broken and loose.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: There is a playground structure that has a bridge with a broken piece which is could cause injury.    Note- Pictures were taken for the file.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: Tables were propped along the classroom wall this is a safety hazard and could cause injury or accident for a child.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: During the walkthrough of the outdoor playground areas, four riding/push toys on the smaller playground were observed to be broken. A photo was taken.    The evacuation crib was observed in the infat room with a broken wheel. This would cause a hazard in the room by not allowing the crib to roll as well and possibly injuring a child on the broken piece. A photo was taken.    During the walkthrough of the toddler room, a table was observed with a broken table leg.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: On the right side of the playground, a section of fence had spaces between bars larger than  3 1/2 inches. An injury can occur to a child if the child places his head, hand, arm or leg into the space.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: On the playground there were two children's barrels which were rusty with broken pieces inside the barrels that could cause injury to a child.      Pictures were taken for the file    Note: This was corrected at inspection when both barrels were removed from the playground.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: Two rolling gates were observed leaning against the fence inside the play area.  The gates could fall on a child causing injury.     There was a broken chair observed in the toddler room.  A child was observed sitting and rocking in the broken chair.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: The carport used for shade has protruding bolts. The bolts can cause serious injury should a child fall onto one of the bolts.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701 - Safety - Areas Free From Hazards

NARRATIVE: It was determined that the operation did not have a child proof outlet in the classroom and did not maintain a child proof cover on the outlet when the injury occurred.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701(1) - Safety - Electrical Outlets Covered

NARRATIVE: Observed an electric fan on the floor in the infant classroom and not mounted or with safeguards that keep any child from being injured at the time of inspection.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701(3) - Safety - Air Conditioners, Fans, Heaters Safeguarded

NARRATIVE: One side of the safeguard around the outside air conditioner unit is broken and was observed laying on the ground. This needs to be replaced or repaired to prevent children from being injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701(3) - Safety - Air Conditioners, Fans, Heaters Safeguarded

NARRATIVE: It was observed that there was a electrical fan on the table in the toddler room.  This fan is within children' reach and can pose a injury.    Caregiver removed the fan out of the classroom during inspection.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701(3) - Safety - Air Conditioners, Fans, Heaters Safeguarded

NARRATIVE: The air conditioners positioned along the sidewalks where children have access did not have proper safeguards. The center had installed a screen mesh over the tops of the air conditioners. The mesh was pulling up on the sides and could cut and injure a child.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701(3) - Safety - Air Conditioners, Fans, Heaters Safeguarded

NARRATIVE: Based on information obtained during the investigation a child was injured by a toy with a sharp or rough edge.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701(5) - Safety - Play Materials and Equipment Safe

NARRATIVE: An edge corner of the whiteboard in Classroom #1 did not have the appropriate protection cover. The edge of the corner was sharp, a child hit the corner and the child obtained an injury.     This was corrected at inspection. The operation ordered a replacement and placed the protection cover on the edge corner of the board.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701(5) - Safety - Play Materials and Equipment Safe

NARRATIVE: A child was allowed to have a (metal) water bottle on the playground, leading to the bottle being thrown causing injury to another child.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701(5) - Safety - Play Materials and Equipment Safe

NARRATIVE: When walking the three years old playground, It  was observed the roof on one of the structures is chipped and/or broken that could injure a child, the wood floor and side boards were not secure and stable in order to ensure safety of the children, it was an structures that simulates a boat, one of the poles were not stable .  ( picture taken)
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3701(5) - Safety - Play Materials and Equipment Safe

NARRATIVE: A medication authorization form was not completed by a parent for a child who received neosporin on an injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3803(a)(1) - Medication Authorization - Signed and Dated

NARRATIVE: A child present at the center is using a medical helmet due to an injury. The center does not have documentation on reason for the device or how it is to be used from a health care professional.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.3815(a) - Specialized Medical Assistance - Provide as Recommended or Ordered by a Health-Care Professional

NARRATIVE: Four preschool age children were playing un an aea which was not fenced when a school age child was injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4305 - Fenced Outdoor Activity Space

NARRATIVE: There were two broken wood boards in different areas of the outdoor playground fence were broken and could cause injuries to children .
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4305 - Fenced Outdoor Activity Space

NARRATIVE: During the course of this investigation it was determined that a broken table was left to use in a classroom which resulted in a child being injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4501 - Tables and Chairs Safe, Easy to Clean and Appropriate in Size

NARRATIVE: There is evidence to prove that caregivers were unable to obtain first aid supplies for an injured child due to not being able to call to the front of the building for assistance.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4507(a)(2)(B) - Access to Telephone in Same Building to Transmit Messages Regarding Children

NARRATIVE: A child was injured while using a ride on toy which specified an age group of 12 months to 36 months of age. The child exceeded the 36 month old age range.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4601(2) - Safety Requirements for Active Play Equipment - Appropriate for Ages of Children

NARRATIVE: A child sustained an injury while playing on play equipment that was not age appropriate.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4601(2) - Safety Requirements for Active Play Equipment - Appropriate for Ages of Children

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated as part of an investigation. An 18 month old child was injured while playing on a piece of playground equipment that is designed for play by children age 2-7.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4601(2) - Safety Requirements for Active Play Equipment - Used According to Manufacturer's Instructions

NARRATIVE: Based on the information obtained, a child was injured while in care because the operation used a bungee cord to strap down an umbrella to a table instead of using a manufactured mechanism to keep the umbrella in it's place.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4601(2) - Safety Requirements for Active Play Equipment - Used According to Manufacturer's Instructions

NARRATIVE: There are three broken toys observed on the playground which could cause injury to the chilren in care.  One is a playhouse with cracked plastic around the window of the structure.  A plastic toy car and a plastic toy horse also have cracks and missing pieces.  The toy structures were removed during inspection.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4601(3) - Safety Requirements for Active Play Equipment - No Entrapment Openings

NARRATIVE: There was a crack at the top of one of the slides on the playground that could cause an injury to a child.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4601(3) - Safety Requirements for Active Play Equipment - No Entrapment Openings

NARRATIVE: The wooden barriers of a play area has a screw protruding out.  This is a safety hazard for the children in care.  Also, one of the wooden barriers is not secured to the ground.  A child could trip or loose their balance causing serious injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4601(4) - Safety Requirements for Active Play Equipment - No Entanglement Protrusions or Openings

NARRATIVE: On the small active play structure, there are screw bolts that protrude from the yellow tunnel connected to the structure.  appear to be long and can be a possible entanglement hazard or injury risk to the children. Note: A picture was taken of the long screw bolts.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4601(4) - Safety Requirements for Active Play Equipment - No Entanglement Protrusions or Openings

NARRATIVE: A play structure was altered from the manufactures specifications. As a result a child received a traumatic injury to a vital part of the child's body where it required immediate medical attention. The child sustained the injury from a fall when climbing the equipment.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4601(5) - Safety Requirements for Active Play Equipment - Securely Anchored

NARRATIVE: Anchoring devices for the center's playground covering were above the play surface.  The anchors could result in injury from a fall.  Picture taken.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4601(6) - Safety Requirements for Active Play Equipment - Anchoring devices Below Level of Playing Surface

NARRATIVE: The play structure in the outdoor play area has several broken areas near the slide and where children may be placing their hands when sliding down. These shear point may cause an injury to a child.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4601(7) - Safety Requirements for Active Play Equipment - No Pinch, Crush, or Shear Points

NARRATIVE: A little tikes activity gym had broken plastic on the small platform area where children sit to slide off. This posed a hazard for children as children could pinch or injure themselves when they sit on the broken plastic part. In addition, the seat to a toddler's push and ride toy was observed to be broken. The seat had two holes measuring about an inch and half each exposing a safety hazard as children could accidentally pinch or injure themselves as they sit to ride the toy.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4601(7) - Safety Requirements for Active Play Equipment - No Pinch, Crush, or Shear Points

NARRATIVE: During the course of this investigation, it was determined that a small trampoline was used without a resilient surface which resulted in a child injuring themselves.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4603(3) - Prohibited Equipment - Trampolines

NARRATIVE: Three year old child in care received an injury while using over head rings.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4605(b)(4) - Equipment Prohibited for Younger Than 4 Yrs - Over-head Rings

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated as part of an investigation and found to be deficient. A child was injured on a piece of equipment that had recently been installed and licensing was not notified of this new installation..
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4609(b) - Height - Licensed Before Dec 1, 2010 - Re-design or New Equipment

NARRATIVE: Broken toys were obversed in the toddlers play area.  Glass and trash was observed in the school age play area.  Discarding broken toys and equipment with sharp edges will prevent a child from being injured.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(a) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Inspect Daily

NARRATIVE: A proper daily check of the playground was not completed. The swing set was not checked by the center director or designee. A swing broke while a child was swinging. The child fell and injured an arm.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(a) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Inspect Daily

NARRATIVE: There were broken ceramic plant pots on the playground area that could cause injury to children during play. There were  broken wooden posts with jagged and /or sharp ends laying on the playground that could be a safety and tripping hazard to the children. The rope from the post fence was hanging loose and laying on the playground, which could be a trip hazard. Several tricycles were missing foot pedals and this should be repaired to prevent injury while using equipment.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(a) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Inspect Daily

NARRATIVE: During this inspection playground structures had missing screws, nuts and bolts. This structure can lead to injuries.    Staff members should ensure that the playgrounds are free of debris and standing water prior to the children engaging in outdoor activities.     The gate and fence need repair as the gate has a gap and the fence has a broken board and nails sticking out.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(b) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Monthly Maintenance Checklist

NARRATIVE: During this inspection playground structures had missing screws, nuts and bolts. This structure can lead to injuries.    The wood frame on the ground holding the loose fill needs to be replace due to it being broken.     There are a two nails sticking out half  inch from the bottom picket fence near the gate door to the back ally.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(b) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Monthly Maintenance Checklist

NARRATIVE: Two pieces of playground equipment were found to be loose and not secure in the ground and could be a potential safety concerns.    One piece of bouncing play equipment on the playground had metal stakes that were not secured in the ground and could be a s tripping hazard and injury hazard.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: Based on information collected during the investigation a child was injured by a broken toy at the operation.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: Children were observed accessing a slide on the preschool playground had a crack in it that could cause an injury to a child in care.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: It was observed during an inspection that the fence had a hole in the bottom of the fence about three inches wide.  This is a safety concern due to potential injury due to entanglement of a child.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: A green little tykes covered slide had a crack in it that was jagged. This could cause an injury to a child by pinching the child, entagling the child, and cutting or scraping a child.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: Observed the following hazards on the playground used by the children in care.    Observed play structure was not anchored on the playground.    Observed trees limbs hanging on the playground along the fence line that needs trimming.    Observed broken toys on the playground that need to be removed.  The broken toys could cause injury to a child. The broken toys were removed at the inspection.    Observed (3) ant piles on the playground it has been raining and children have not be out.    Observed the fence on the playground area in need of repair at inspection.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: The operation has two wide openings on their playground structure that could lead to serious injury if a child was to fall through one of the openings.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: Observed the hazards on the outside play area.     1. Wooden playscape with worn areas that are a potential hazard for injury such as splinters.    2. Outside bouncer equipment with a broken seat with sharp edges which could cause a potential injury to a child.    3. A toy with broken part with sharp edges. The toy was removed at the inspection.    4.  Tires with debris such as leaves and standing water.  The leaves are hiding places for insects or rodents.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: There is a metal handle on the wall that could injure a child who runs into it.     There are pieces of tape coming up that children could catch their feet on and fall.    Part of one of the wooden boarders has come loose. A child's hand could get caught in between the two pieces of wood.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: A large metal box with pointed corners was observed on the side of the building in a fenced outdoor area to be used by children. The box is installed at a height where a child could bump into the corner of the box causing injury. This was discussed with the director/ owner during the inspection.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: There is a plastic playhouse on the playground that has a torn window sill that is sharp and could injure a child in care.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: The climbing playground equipment  that the child was playing on at the time of injury was found to be loose and not secure in the ground and could have caused the child to slip and lose footing resulting in his injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: There was a toy on the playground with a broken yellow competent in the middle. The yellow component was sharp and could easily cause an injury to child who utilizes the toy.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: The blue tarp located beneath the pea gravel on the playground is showing on many areas of the playground posing a possible tripping hazard. The tarp should be burried below the pea gravel to reduce the risk of injury. The playground should be checked daily to ensure the tarp is no longer showing or exposed above the gravel.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: Swing set in the playground has been at the operation for over 10 years. Proper maintenance has not been provided. As a result of this, a swing broke and a child fell causing an injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: Two of the beams surrounding the playground need to be replaced or repaired, it is broken and has exposed splinters that could cause injury to a child.  There is also a nail protruding out of one of the beams in front of the slide that needs to be removed or repaired.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4751(c) - Maintenance Procedures for Active Play - Hazards Removed or Repaired

NARRATIVE: On the 12-24 month playground, the use zone (fall/play space) for three stationary pieces of play equipment overlap posing a risk of injury if the children run into each other or fall while using the equipment.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4803 - Measurement of Use Zone for Stationary Equipment

NARRATIVE: I observed two pieces of stationary equipment with use zones overlaping.  The measurements should extend a total of 12 feet.  Overlaping of use zone could cause a child to fall or trip onto a piece of equipment which could pose an injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4803 - Measurement of Use Zone for Stationary Equipment

NARRATIVE: The use zone at the exit of the double slide measures 3'6". The use zone at the exit of the single slide measures 3'2".    Note: a safety plan was put in place at inspection.  To prevent accidental injury, children must not use the play structure containing the slides until the use zones are corrected.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4805(a) - Measurement of Use Zone for Slides - in Front of Access and on Sides

NARRATIVE: One piece of outdoor equipment equipped with springs and provides a rocking motion is lacking surfacing to reduce injury with any fall.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4901(a) - Active Play Surfacing In Use Zones - Loose Fill or Unitary Surfacing

NARRATIVE: The surfacing under the area in with the child was injured did not have the required amount of surfacing.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4901(a) - Active Play Surfacing In Use Zones - Loose Fill or Unitary Surfacing

NARRATIVE: An indoor loft in the two-year old classroom measured 23 inches above the ground. There was no surfacing around the slide area or the stairs preventing children from falling and causing and injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4901(a) - Active Play Surfacing In Use Zones - Loose Fill or Unitary Surfacing

NARRATIVE: The outdoor play area does not have any surfacing material in the use zone, which can decrease the amount of injuries that may occur.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4901(a) - Active Play Surfacing In Use Zones - Loose Fill or Unitary Surfacing

NARRATIVE: The surfacing under swings on the playground is compacted under fake grass turf. The loose fill is compacted and no longer provides any level of shock absorption. Additionally the playground contains a merry go round that requires loose fill to prevent injuries.     *Pictures taken
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4901(a) - Active Play Surfacing In Use Zones - Loose Fill or Unitary Surfacing

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated with regard to an investigation.  I observed the playground where the child was injured.  There was rubber surfacing but it did not have the required 6 inches in all the use zones as required.   There is only an inch of surfacing in most areas.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4907(a)(1) - Installation and Maintenance of Loose-fill Surfacing - Six Inches if Equipment 5 Ft or Less

NARRATIVE: Based on the information received there was a slide on the outdoor playground with no surfacing when a child in care fell off and was injured while in care.     Note: The slide was removed from the playground after the incident.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4907(a)(1) - Installation and Maintenance of Loose-fill Surfacing - Six Inches if Equipment 5 Ft or Less

NARRATIVE: Owner had called and said that all loose fill was in compliance. The older playgrounds have enough loose fill in use zones. The toddler playground does not have enough loose fill and the wood chips are very large and increase the risk of injury rather than reduce the risk.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4907(a)(1) - Installation and Maintenance of Loose-fill Surfacing - Six Inches if Equipment 5 Ft or Less

NARRATIVE: There were large patches of grass visible in the playground mulch.  It has been compacted down and is not loose fill material. The mulch needs to be raked to prevent injury.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4907(a)(1) - Installation and Maintenance of Loose-fill Surfacing - Six Inches if Equipment 5 Ft or Less

NARRATIVE: The playground area did not have enough loose fill to reduce the risk of an  injury by the playground equipment.  The loose fill were in bags stacked around the playground barriers.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4907(a)(1) - Installation and Maintenance of Loose-fill Surfacing - Six Inches if Equipment 5 Ft or Less

NARRATIVE: The pea gravel in the large outdoor has has been reduced due to usage and weather. The amount of pea gravel under and around the climbing structure is less than six inches. The amount must be increased to six nches to reduce the risk of injury to children if they fall and the poles must be marked at the six inch level so that staff will know when the amount of pea gravel is not sufficient.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4907(a)(1) - Installation and Maintenance of Loose-fill Surfacing - Six Inches if Equipment 5 Ft or Less

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated as part of an investigation. The area where a child was injured did not require loose fill, however the use zone around the slide needs loose fill. .
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4907(a)(1) - Installation and Maintenance of Loose-fill Surfacing - Six Inches if Equipment 5 Ft or Less

NARRATIVE: Wood chips in the use zone are much too big and sharp. Some of the pieces are at least 6 inches long and pointed and could seriously injure a child if they fell on it. Many children were seen running and chasing their friends with large pieces of it in their hands.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4907(a)(1) - Installation and Maintenance of Loose-fill Surfacing - Six Inches if Equipment 5 Ft or Less

NARRATIVE: As of 12/23/15, the loose fill material under the swings and different areas of the playground for the school age children was less than one inch deep.    As of 11/06/15, the loose fill under the monkey bars in the playground where the child was injured was less than one inch deep.     Pictures are available in the case file.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4907(a)(2) - Installation and Maintenance of Loose-fill Surfacing - Nine Inches if Equipment Greater Than 5 Ft.

NARRATIVE: The loose fill under the monkey bars in the playground where the child was injured was less than one inch deep.     Pictures are available in the case file.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4907(a)(2) - Installation and Maintenance of Loose-fill Surfacing - Nine Inches if Equipment Greater Than 5 Ft.

NARRATIVE: The playground surfacing on both the toddler playground and the preschool playground was not maintained, resulting in a child on the toddler playground to become injured and require medical treatment.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4907(d) - Installation and Maintenance of Loose-fill Surfacing - Proper Depth Maintained

NARRATIVE: The unitary surfacing under a play structure is hard and compact. It would not suffiiciently absorb the shock of a fall and result in more serious injuries.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4911(a) - Installation of Unitary Surfacing Materials - to Manufacturer's Specifications

NARRATIVE: Based on the information gathered and obtained during this investigation, it was determined that the operation did not have documentation to demonstrate that the unitary surfacing in place was installed and maintained according to manufacturer instructions to ensure that unitary surfacing  material would aid in prevention of injuries during a fall on to surfacing material.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4911(a) - Installation of Unitary Surfacing Materials - to Manufacturer's Specifications

NARRATIVE: This standard was evaluated with regards to an investigation and found to be deficient.   The operation did not properly maintain the soft contained play equipment used by children in care.  The protective pad on a metal bar was loose exposing the metal bar. Consequently, a child sustained an injury that required medical attention.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 746.4953(4) - Safety Requirments of SCPE - Installed, Maintained and Cleaned

NARRATIVE: A child received an injury that required stitches while playing on the second level of a soft contained play structure. The caregiver had lost visual, auditory and proximity supervision of the child when the caregiver left the area to briefly get something from the kitchen. NARRATIVE: The applicant did not have training on: (A) recognizing and preventing shaken baby syndrome and abusive head trauma; (B) understanding and using safe sleep practices and preventing sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS); (C) understanding early childhood brain development; (D) emergency preparedness; (E) preventing and controlling the spread of communicable diseases, including immunizations; (F) administering medication; (G) preventing and responding to emergencies due to food or an allergic reaction; (H) understanding building and physical premises safety, including identification and protection from hazards that can cause bodily injury such as electric hazards, bodies of water, and vehicular traffic; and (I) handling, storing, and disposing of hazardous materials.

NARRATIVE: The caregiver has not have any of following trainings to meet the qualifications of the primary caregiver of a registered child-care home :          (A) Recognizing and preventing shaken baby syndrome and abusive head trauma;          (B) Understanding and using safe sleep practices and preventing sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS);            (C) Understanding early childhood brain development;                    (D) Emergency preparedness;            (E) Preventing and controlling the spread of communicable diseases, including immunizations;            (F) Administering medication, if applicable, including compliance with ?747.3603 of this title (relating to What authorization must I obtain before administering a medication to a child in my care?);            (G) Preventing and responding to emergencies due to food and allergic reaction;            (H) Understanding building and physical premises safety, including identification and protection from hazards that can cause bodily injury such as electric hazards, bodies of water, and vehicular traffic;            (I) Handling, storing, and disposing of hazardous materials including compliance with ?747.3221 of this title (relating to Must caregivers wear gloves when handling blood or bodily fluids containing blood?);           and  (J) Precautions in transporting children if your child-care home plans to transport a child whose chronological or developmental age is younger than nine years old. STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 747.1309(e) - Primary Caregiver Annual Training - Required Special Topics without specific hours

NARRATIVE: Caregiver did not use good judgemnedet when caregiver directed children to climb a kidney table on their own. By allowing children to climb the table there is a possiblility of children falling and sustaining and injury. When the children were observed climbing on and off the table other children were eating and this contributes to cross contamination.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 747.1501(b) - Responsibilities of Caregivers-Report Suspected Child Abuse, Neglect or Exploitation to DFPS Or Law Enforcement

NARRATIVE: Caregivers failed to use good judgment by having a 6 month old infant sleep on the couch with a blanket folded under. The infant was also covered with another blanket and had a bib on its neck. This put the infant at increased risk of injury/death due to an unsafe sleep environment.      A second infant under 6 months was observed sleeping in a  bouncer, covered with a towel. Caregivers failed to use good judgment by using a bouncer, which is restrictive, to allow the infant to sleep in thus putting the infant at risk due to an unsafe sleep environment.     Pack and plays were available for infants to nap in however, caregivers did not put the sleeping infants there but let them sleep on the couch and bouncer.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 747.1501(c)(1) - Responsibilities of Employees and Caregivers -Competency, Good Judgment, Self-control

NARRATIVE: A caregiver did not demonstrate good judgment in leaving a child on a toilet without proper accommodations for the child to get off the toilet independently. As a result, the child fell off the toilet and sustained a minor head injury. Additionally, the caregiver did not use good judgment in contacting the parent sooner, as the injury involved the head.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 747.1501(c)(1) - Responsibilities of Employees and Caregivers -Competency,Good Judgment,Self-control

NARRATIVE: A caregiver did not use good judgment when a child in care was injured as a result of almost falling from a diaper changing table.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 747.1501(c)(1) - Responsibilities of Employees and Caregivers -Competency,Good Judgment,Self-control

NARRATIVE: A 2 year old child was observed sleeping in a crib with the mattress on the highest setting.  If the infant sat up, the infant's head and chest would be higher than the crib railing.  This could be a hazard causing the child falling out of the bed and injuring themselves.      The caregiver was also observed chainge an infant's diaper in her lap at the table in the daycare room.
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 747.1501(c)(1) - Responsibilities of Employees and Caregivers -Competency,Good Judgment,Self-control

NARRATIVE: Caregiver did not use good judgment when caregiver directed children to climb a kidney table on their own. By allowing children to climb the table there is a possibility of children falling and sustaining and injury. When the children were observed climbing on and off the table other children were eating and this contributes to cross contamination.    Caregiver did not use good judge when caregiver left child sitting on kidney table while attending to another child.    RECITE
STANDARD_NUMBER_DESCRIPTION: 747.1501(c)(1) - Responsibilities of Employees and Caregivers -Competency,Good Judgment,Self-control

NARRATIVE: A report was received alleging that a child was injured while in care. Based on the information gathered during this investigation a child was bitten several times by another child when the caregiver stepped out of the room to attend to another duty. The caregiver had previous knowledge biting incidents occur and did not provide appropriate supervision.

NARRATIVE: The primary caregiver left a group of children from the ages of 13 months to 4 years old unsupervised in a room for about 15 minutes on 1/8/2015, while she was in the kitchen preparing lunch. During the time that the children were unsupervised an infant in care was injured.
